steps.title: Rub down the arrow shaft with denatured alcohol on a clean rag.
steps.content: Rub down the arrow shaft with denatured alcohol on a clean rag. [1] X Research source

steps.title: Decide whether you want straight fletchings, off-set fletchings, or helical fletchings and adjust your jig accordingly.
steps.content: Decide whether you want straight fletchings, off-set fletchings, or helical fletchings and adjust your jig accordingly. Straight fletchings are those which sit on a straight line along the arrow shaft. Off-set or helical fletchings grasp the shaft at an angle or twist along the shaft, introducing torque in the arrow's flight for increased range.

steps.title: Fletching by hand is incredibly hard, so use a fletching jig.
steps.content: Fletching by hand is incredibly hard, so use a fletching jig. Adjust its position depending on the type of fletching you've decided to use. [2] X Research source

steps.title: You’ll want to mark off 1 1⁄2 inches (3.8 cm) from the end of the shaft.
steps.content: You’ll want to mark off 1 1 ⁄ 2 inches (3.8 cm) from the end of the shaft. Use a grease pencil or marker to mark the spot.

steps.title: Position the fletching in the jig.
steps.content: Position the fletching in the jig. Use the jig's measurement feature to line up the fletching with how far it will be from the end of the arrow shaft. [3] X Research source

steps.title: Line everything up in your jig.
steps.content: Line everything up in your jig. Take particular care to line it up evenly and at the appropriate measurements so that the fletching will adhere evenly and in the right spot.

steps.title: Add glue from the spot you measured to the opposite end of the arrow shaft.
steps.content: Add glue from the spot you measured to the opposite end of the arrow shaft. The glue should be in a line equal to the length of your type of fletching. Adjust the direction of your glue line for off-set or helical fletchings. [4] X Research source

steps.title: Apply glue to the rim where you’re going to fletch the arrow.
steps.content: Apply glue to the rim where you’re going to fletch the arrow. Do not use too much glue, as this will spill out and affect the flight of your arrow. [5] X Research source

steps.title: Lower the clamp onto the jig and the arrow.
steps.content: Lower the clamp onto the jig and the arrow. A magnet built into the jig should keep the clamp tight without you having to hold it.

steps.title: Wait at least 5 minutes to give the glue time to cure.
steps.content: Wait at least 5 minutes to give the glue time to cure. It shouldn’t take too long for the glue to harden.

steps.title: Test the strength of the fletching when you take it out.
steps.content: Test the strength of the fletching when you take it out. Gently push on the fletching to ensure that it doesn’t move.

steps.title: Add a small dollop to the front of each feather.
steps.content: Add a small dollop to the front of each feather. Do this at the end of each arrow. Pro-tip: You can also put a dot of glue on the tip of each arrow, too. This will keep any leaves or branches from sticking to your arrow when you fire it.

steps.title: You can use and shoot the arrows after a few hours.
steps.content: You can use and shoot the arrows after a few hours. It doesn’t take super long for the arrow to become usable.
